Abstract.

Let fğ‘“f be a Sâ€‹Lâ€‹(2,â„¤)ğ‘†ğ¿2â„¤SL(2,\mathbb{Z}) Hecke cusp form, and let Ï‡ğœ’\chi be a primitive Dirichlet character modulo Mğ‘€M, which we assume to be prime. We prove the Burgess type bound for the twisted Lğ¿L-function:

Lâ€‹(12,fâŠ—Ï‡)â‰ªf,ÎµM1/2âˆ’1/8+Îµ.subscriptmuch-less-thanğ‘“ğœ€ğ¿12tensor-productğ‘“ğœ’superscriptğ‘€1218ğœ€\displaystyle L\left(\tfrac{1}{2},f\otimes\chi\right)\ll_{f,\varepsilon}M^{1/2-1/8+\varepsilon}.

The method also yields the original bound of Burgess for Dirichlet Lğ¿L-functions:

Lâ€‹(12,Ï‡)â‰ªÎµM1/4âˆ’1/16+Îµ.subscriptmuch-less-thanğœ€ğ¿12ğœ’superscriptğ‘€14116ğœ€\displaystyle L\left(\tfrac{1}{2},\chi\right)\ll_{\varepsilon}M^{1/4-1/16+\varepsilon}.

1. Introduction

In the series of papers [15], [16], [17], [18] and [20] a new approach to prove subconvexity has been proposed. This method has turned out to be quite effective in the case of degree three Lğ¿L-functions. Indeed if Ï€ğœ‹\pi is a Sâ€‹Lâ€‹(3,â„¤)ğ‘†ğ¿3â„¤SL(3,\mathbb{Z}) Hecke-Maass cusp form then the tğ‘¡t aspect subconvex bound

Lâ€‹(12+iâ€‹t,Ï€)â‰ª(2+|t|)3/4âˆ’1/16+Îµ,much-less-thanğ¿12ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœ‹superscript2ğ‘¡34116ğœ€\displaystyle L(\tfrac{1}{2}+it,\pi)\ll(2+|t|)^{3/4-1/16+\varepsilon},

was established in [17], and if Ï‡ğœ’\chi is a primitive Dirichlet character modulo a prime Mğ‘€M, then the twist aspect subconvex bound

Lâ€‹(12,Ï€âŠ—Ï‡)â‰ªM3/4âˆ’1/308+Îµ,much-less-thanğ¿12tensor-productğœ‹ğœ’superscriptğ‘€341308ğœ€\displaystyle L(\tfrac{1}{2},\pi\otimes\chi)\ll M^{3/4-1/308+\varepsilon},

was established in [18] and [20]. In the special case, where Ï€ğœ‹\pi is a symmetric square lift of a Sâ€‹Lâ€‹(2,â„¤)ğ‘†ğ¿2â„¤SL(2,\mathbb{Z}) form, then the former bound was previously obtained by Li [13], building on the work of Conrey and Iwaniec [8]. Again for Ï€ğœ‹\pi a symmetric square lift and Ï‡ğœ’\chi a quadratic character, a subconvex bound (with a much stronger exponent) in the latter case was previously obtained by Blomer [2]. The works of Li and Blomer fail to extend to the general case as the non-negativity of the central value of Lğ¿L-functions, which plays a vital role in their approach, ceases to hold in general. In contrast the method of [17], [18], [20] does not rely on this delicate feature.

Recently, Aggarwal [1] showed that the computations in [17] when adapted in the Gâ€‹Lâ€‹(2)ğºğ¿2GL(2) scenario yields the Burgess exponent in the tğ‘¡t aspect. Taking a step further, refining certain estimates for exponential integral in [17], Singh [22] established the Weyl exponent in the tğ‘¡t aspect for Gâ€‹Lâ€‹(2)ğºğ¿2GL(2) Lğ¿L-functions

Lâ€‹(12+iâ€‹t,g)â‰ª(2+|t|)1/3+Îµ.much-less-thanğ¿12ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘”superscript2ğ‘¡13ğœ€\displaystyle L(\tfrac{1}{2}+it,g)\ll(2+|t|)^{1/3+\varepsilon}.

Here gğ‘”g is a Hecke modular or a Maass cuspform. This is of course the celebrated result of Good [10], which still remains the record though the corresponding exponent for the Riemann zeta function Î¶â€‹(s)ğœğ‘ \zeta(s) has gone through several improvements. It is now natural to ask what would one get if one had adopted the method of [18], [20], in the Gâ€‹Lâ€‹(2)ğºğ¿2GL(2) context. The aim of the present note is to give a brief analysis of this possibility. We show that the method yields the Burgess type bound.

Theorem 1.

Suppose gğ‘”g is a Sâ€‹Lâ€‹(2,â„¤)ğ‘†ğ¿2â„¤SL(2,\mathbb{Z}) Hecke cusp form, and Ï‡ğœ’\chi is a primitive Dirichlet character modulo Mğ‘€M (which we assume to be prime). Then we have

Lâ€‹(12,gâŠ—Ï‡)â‰ªM1/2âˆ’1/8+Îµ.much-less-thanğ¿12tensor-productğ‘”ğœ’superscriptğ‘€1218ğœ€\displaystyle L\left(\tfrac{1}{2},g\otimes\chi\right)\ll M^{1/2-1/8+\varepsilon}. (1)

The exponent 1/2+Îµ12ğœ€1/2+\varepsilon corresponds to the convexity bound, which follows easily from the functional equation and basic complex analysis. The Riemann Hypothesis for Lâ€‹(s,gâŠ—Ï‡)ğ¿ğ‘ tensor-productğ‘”ğœ’L(s,g\otimes\chi) implies the much stronger bound - the Lindelof Hypothesis -

Lâ€‹(12,gâŠ—Ï‡)â‰ªMÎµ.much-less-thanğ¿12tensor-productğ‘”ğœ’superscriptğ‘€ğœ€\displaystyle L\left(\tfrac{1}{2},g\otimes\chi\right)\ll M^{\varepsilon}.

Our result (1) is of course not new. Blomer and Harcos [3] established the Burgess exponent using Bykovskiiâ€™s method. The weaker exponent 1/2âˆ’(1âˆ’2â€‹Î¸)/81212ğœƒ81/2-(1-2\theta)/8, where Î¸ğœƒ\theta is the exponent towards the Ramanujan conjecture, was previously established by Blomer, Harcos and Michel [4]. The latter exponent becomes Burgess under the Ramanujan conjecture Î¸=0ğœƒ0\theta=0. The first non-trivial bound of this sort, albeit with a weaker exponent, was obtained by Duke, Friedlander and Iwaniec [9]. The Burgess bound, even in the original set up of Burgess [7] for Dirichlet Lğ¿L-functions, still remains the record (though it has been improved in certain special cases - see e.g. [5], [8], [14], [21]). Any improvement over this will be a major breakthrough in the field.

Our analysis should work even when Mğ‘€M is not a prime, but for simplicity we only provide a sketch for Mğ‘€M prime. From the technical point of view this paper puts the Gâ€‹Lâ€‹(2)ğºğ¿2GL(2) delta method of [19], [20] in a better perspective. We closely follow [20]. In particular, we use the Gâ€‹Lâ€‹(2)ğºğ¿2GL(2) analogue of the â€˜congruence-equation trickâ€™ (see [6], [16], [19]) and the trick of splitting a dual variable of summation to optimize the saving after an application of Cauchy inequality. The Gâ€‹Lâ€‹(2)ğºğ¿2GL(2) set up simplifies certain technicalities, e.g. there is no need to sum over the modulus after dualization. However the extra sum over the level of forms (i.e. pğ‘p below) becomes redundant. This phenomenon is typical in Gâ€‹Lâ€‹(2)ğºğ¿2GL(2) set up, and that this sum provides the extra harmonics needed in the degree three case indicates that one should try to understand this in the amplification technique set up so as to extend that technique beyond Gâ€‹Lâ€‹(2)ğºğ¿2GL(2). We also observe that the cuspidality of gğ‘”g is not required in the proof, and the proof holds even when the Fourier coefficient Î»gâ€‹(n)subscriptğœ†ğ‘”ğ‘›\lambda_{g}(n) is replaced by the divisor function dâ€‹(n)ğ‘‘ğ‘›d(n). In this way we can derive the classic result of Burgess.

Theorem 2.

Suppose Ï‡ğœ’\chi is a primitive Dirichlet character modulo Mğ‘€M (which we assume to be prime). Then we have

Lâ€‹(12,Ï‡)â‰ªM1/4âˆ’1/16+Îµ.much-less-thanğ¿12ğœ’superscriptğ‘€14116ğœ€\displaystyle L\left(\tfrac{1}{2},\chi\right)\ll M^{1/4-1/16+\varepsilon}. (2)

3. The set up

Let gğ‘”g be a fixed cusp form for Sâ€‹Lâ€‹(2,â„¤)ğ‘†ğ¿2â„¤SL(2,\mathbb{Z}) with normalized Fourier coefficients Î»gâ€‹(n)subscriptğœ†ğ‘”ğ‘›\lambda_{g}(n). Let Ï‡ğœ’\chi be a primitive Dirichlet character modulo a prime Mğ‘€M. The approximate functional equation for the twisted Lğ¿L-function yields

Lâ€‹(12,gâŠ—Ï‡)â‰ªMÎµâ€‹supN|Sâ€‹(N)|N1/2+M(1âˆ’Î¸)/2much-less-thanğ¿12tensor-productğ‘”ğœ’superscriptğ‘€ğœ€subscriptsupremumğ‘ğ‘†ğ‘superscriptğ‘12superscriptğ‘€1ğœƒ2\displaystyle L\left(\tfrac{1}{2},g\otimes\chi\right)\ll M^{\varepsilon}\sup_{N}\frac{|S(N)|}{N^{1/2}}+M^{(1-\theta)/2}

Sâ€‹(N)=âˆ‘n=1âˆÎ»gâ€‹(n)â€‹Ï‡â€‹(n)â€‹Wâ€‹(nN)ğ‘†ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1subscriptğœ†ğ‘”ğ‘›ğœ’ğ‘›ğ‘Šğ‘›ğ‘\displaystyle S(N)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\lambda_{g}(n)\chi(n)W\left(\frac{n}{N}\right)

with Wğ‘ŠW a smooth bump function supported on [1,2]12[1,2]. We will use the Gâ€‹Lâ€‹(2)ğºğ¿2GL(2) delta method to separate the oscillations of the Fourier coefficients and the character in the above sum.
